thread.title: 'Star Wars' Fans Are Freaking Out Because 'Jedi' In 'The Last Jedi' Is Plural
thread.title_full: 'Star Wars' Fans Are Freaking Out Because 'Jedi' In 'The Last Jedi' Is Plural

author: Jenna Amatulli
title: 'Star Wars' Fans Are Freaking Out Because 'Jedi' In 'The Last Jedi' Is Plural
text:
'Star Wars' Fans Are Freaking Out Because 'Jedi' In 'The Last Jedi' Is Plural Look to the non-English film posters. 
Speculation about the ninth film in the “ Star Wars ” franchise, “ The Last Jedi,” cropped up as soon as the title was revealed. 
The latest rumor pertains to what’s been featured on the non-English posters for the film. 
Fans on Twitter have noticed that “Jedi” in “The Last Jedi” is plural in both the German and French titles. #StarWars #TheLastJedi is #plural ! The German title, as well as the French, confirmed it! The singular title would be "Der letzte Jedi" pic.twitter.com/v1kcUuqJqv — Mack Paxton (@MackPaxton) February 17, 2017 NOT A DRILL I REPEAT THIS IS NOT A DRILL!"THE LAST JEDI" IS PLURAL. #StarWars pic.twitter.com/kkVGLK9mT0 — Star Wars España (@StarWarsSpain) February 17, 2017 
Since the plural and singular forms of “Jedi” in English are the same, the foreign language posters indicate that the title doesn’t refer to just one Jedi, but several (or at least two). 
The pluralization could signal that Luke Skywalker, a Jedi, isn’t going to be killed. Many fans had wondered whether, if the “Jedi” in the title were singular, that Luke would have to die in order to leave Rey as the titular “Last Jedi.” Really, all this means is that Luke won’t be the last Jedi. Jedi in the plural form. Interesting... — Jezreel C. Castillo (@dezastron) February 17, 2017 @b_hawk I've always wondered, if "jedi" is plural, shouldn't the singular be "jedus"? — T.S. Wingard (@Physiololgus) February 17, 2017 @Physiololgus That's only assuming "Jedi" is Latin; & I assume it's not. It is used in both singular & plural in the original trilogy.
